abstract: A type that describes a CloudKit error.
overview:
## Overview

CloudKit provides operations that faciliate moving data between your app and iCloud. There are also convenience methods in [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKContainer] and [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKDatabase] that provide similar functionality. If an operation or method fails to complete its task, CloudKit provides detailed error information that you can use to recover. A failure might be due to network or server conditions, or because of conflicts between local and remote data. For a list of possible reasons, see [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/Code].

If you receive an error, cast it to an instance of `CKError` to access additional information that CloudKit provides. For example, if the error code is [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/requestRateLimited], you can use the [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/retryAfterSeconds] property to determine how long you must wait before you retry the operation or method.

Batch operations, such as [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKModifyRecordsOperation], can complete with a [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/partialFailure] error. This means only a subset of the operation’s changes succeed. Use the [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/partialErrorsByItemID] property to access a dictionary that maps items that CloudKit can’t process to errors that describe those failures. You can then handle each error independently.

If you attempt to save a record and the server’s version of that record is newer, CloudKit returns a [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/serverRecordChanged] error. Use the [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/ancestorRecord], [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/clientRecord], and [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/serverRecord] properties to resolve the conflict. Make sure you merge any changes into `serverRecord` because that version contains the most recent change tag.
rawMarkdown:
---
source: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/CloudKit/CKError
crawled: 2025-12-04T19:14:26Z
---

# CKError

**Structure**

A type that describes a CloudKit error.

## Declaration

```swift
struct CKError
```

## Overview

CloudKit provides operations that faciliate moving data between your app and iCloud. There are also convenience methods in [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKContainer] and [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKDatabase] that provide similar functionality. If an operation or method fails to complete its task, CloudKit provides detailed error information that you can use to recover. A failure might be due to network or server conditions, or because of conflicts between local and remote data. For a list of possible reasons, see [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/Code].

If you receive an error, cast it to an instance of `CKError` to access additional information that CloudKit provides. For example, if the error code is [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/requestRateLimited], you can use the [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/retryAfterSeconds] property to determine how long you must wait before you retry the operation or method.

Batch operations, such as [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKModifyRecordsOperation], can complete with a [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/partialFailure] error. This means only a subset of the operation’s changes succeed. Use the [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/partialErrorsByItemID] property to access a dictionary that maps items that CloudKit can’t process to errors that describe those failures. You can then handle each error independently.

If you attempt to save a record and the server’s version of that record is newer, CloudKit returns a [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/serverRecordChanged] error. Use the [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/ancestorRecord], [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/clientRecord], and [doc://com.apple.cloudkit/documentation/CloudKit/CKError/serverRecord] properties to resolve the conflict. Make sure you merge any changes into `serverRecord` because that version contains the most recent change tag.

## Getting Error Codes

- **accountTemporarilyUnavailable**: An error that occurs when the user’s iCloud account is temporarily unavailable.
- **alreadyShared**: An error that occurs when CloudKit attempts to share a record with an existing share.
- **assetFileModified**: An error that occurs when the system modifies an asset while saving it.
- **assetFileNotFound**: An error that occurs when the system can’t find the specified asset.
- **assetNotAvailable**: An error that occurs when the system can’t access the specified asset.
- **badContainer**: An error that occurs when you use an unknown or unauthorized container.
- **badDatabase**: An error that occurs when the operation can’t complete for the specified database.
- **batchRequestFailed**: An error that occurs when the system rejects the entire batch of changes.
- **changeTokenExpired**: An error that occurs when the change token expires.
- **constraintViolation**: An error that occurs when the server rejects the request because of a unique constraint violation.
- **incompatibleVersion**: An error that occurs when the current app version is older than the oldest allowed version.
- **internalError**: A nonrecoverable error that CloudKit encounters.
- **invalidArguments**: An error that occurs when the request contains invalid information.
- **limitExceeded**: An error that occurs when a request’s size exceeds the limit.
- **managedAccountRestricted**: An error that occurs when CloudKit rejects a request due to a managed-account restriction.
- **missingEntitlement**: An error that occurs when the app is missing a required entitlement.
- **networkFailure**: An error that occurs when a network is available, but CloudKit is inaccessible.
- **networkUnavailable**: An error that occurs when the network is unavailable.
- **notAuthenticated**: An error that occurs when the user is unauthenticated.
- **operationCancelled**: An error that occurs when an operation cancels.
- **partialFailure**: An error that occurs when an operation completes with partial failures.
- **participantMayNeedVerification**: An error that occurs when the user isn’t a participant of the share.
- **permissionFailure**: An error that occurs when the user doesn’t have permission to save or fetch data.
- **quotaExceeded**: An error that occurs when saving a record exceeds the user’s storage quota.
- **referenceViolation**: An error that occurs when CloudKit can’t find the target of a reference.
- **requestRateLimited**: An error that occurs when CloudKit rate-limits requests.
- **serverRecordChanged**: An error that occurs when CloudKit rejects a record because the server’s version is different.
- **serverRejectedRequest**: An error that occurs when CloudKit rejects the request.
- **serverResponseLost**: An error that occurs when CloudKit is unable to maintain the network connection and provide a response.
- **serviceUnavailable**: An error that occurs when CloudKit is unavailable.
- **tooManyParticipants**: An error that occurs when a share has too many participants.
- **unknownItem**: An error that occurs when the specified record doesn’t exist.
- **userDeletedZone**: An error that occurs when the user deletes a record zone using the Settings app.
- **zoneBusy**: An error that occurs when the server is too busy to handle the record zone operation.
- **zoneNotFound**: An error that occurs when the specified record zone doesn’t exist.
- **resultsTruncated**: An error that occurs when CloudKit truncates a query’s results.
- **CKError.Code**: The error codes that CloudKit returns.

## Getting Partial Errors

- **partialErrorsByItemID**: The dictionary that contains errors that relate to individual record operations.

## Getting Conflicted Records

- **ancestorRecord**: The original version of the record.
- **clientRecord**: The local version of the record that includes any changes.
- **serverRecord**: The server’s version of the record.

## Getting Retry Information

- **retryAfterSeconds**: The number of seconds to wait before you retry the request.

## Type Properties

- **errorDomain**
- **participantAlreadyInvited**

## Errors

- **CKErrorDomain**: The error domain for CloudKit errors.
- **CKError.Code**: The error codes that CloudKit returns.
- **CKErrorRetryAfterKey**: The key to retrieve the number of seconds to wait before you retry a request.
- **CKErrorUserDidResetEncryptedDataKey**: The key that determines whether CloudKit deletes a record zone because of a user action.
- **CKPartialErrorsByItemIDKey**: The key to retrieve partial errors.
- **Record Changed Error Keys**: Constants that represent conflicting records in a save operation.

## Conforms To

- CustomNSError
- Equatable
- Error
- Hashable
- Sendable
- SendableMetatype
